headline: Chicken and Red Wine Sauce
description: This chicken and red wine recipe has balanced flavor from brown sugar, garlic, and paprika. Enjoy this simple, comforting dish with a delicious sauce.
name: Chicken and Red Wine Sauce
recipeIngredient: 3 pounds skinless, boneless chicken breast halves

recipeInstructions.text: Heat oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Cook garlic in oil until tender.

Place chicken in the skillet, and cook for about 10 minutes on each side, until no longer pink and juices run clear. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read at least 165 degrees F (74 degrees C).
Drain oil from the skillet. Sprinkle chicken with paprika and brown sugar.
Pour red wine around chicken. Cover and simmer, 15 to 20 minutes; lightly baste the chicken with wine sauce while cooking. Season with salt and pepper.

review.reviewBody: Way too sweet No other flavours came through than the brown sugar
Loved it easy, simple and delicious üòã

Added some onion. After removing the chicken caramelizedthe onion then added the garlic. Reduced the sugar and increased the wine as suggested. Added Corn starch to thicken the sauce. Next time, more garlic for the garlic lovers, but next time.
This is too sweet and too dry. Not good.

My Husband and I really liked this, it could use a little more sauce, but he thinks everything can use more sauce. I just used about 3 Spoonfuls of brown sugar, and of course added more garlic. I will make it again

I used bone-in thighs, browned those first then added garlic & frozen stew vegetables (baby potatoes, pearl onions, carrots, celery). Sprinkled 1/4 cup brown sugar over chicken & veg, added wine & simmered about 40min. Sauce is in the fridge so I can defat it before reheating with chicken & veg, but it tastes very good. üëç
This chicken recipe has everything I'm looking for in a chicken recipe! Easy, quick and delicious. It's very good with baked sweet potatoes, and is also really good cold the next day on a salad!
Tender, good flavor, but overly sweet. Would definitely use half the brown sugar.

This is a really different recipe, easy and delicious. I altered the recipe by first marinating chicken thighs in Soy Vay Island Teriyaki marinade (Kroger) for about a half hour.? I only used about a quarter cup of the brown sugar, half a cup of wine and reduced with cover off due to the extra marinade liquid.? I only used about 1/4 cup of the brown sugar, 1/2 cup of wine and reduced with cover off due to the extra marinade liquid. I topped with chopped fresh green onions to serve.
Delicious! My whole family loved this.

This is an amazing and easy entree to make. Yet, it comes out looking like a 5-star dish when you're done. I highly recommend it. 

I do have a suggestion on a different way of preparing the dish. The first few times I made it, I put the whole chicken breast in (2 or 3 at a time) and they came out beautifully. Nothing really NEEDED to be changed, but I wanted to try something different. So I cut the breast into 1 in x 1 in pieces with about 1/2 in thickness and put them all in a plastic bag. I then added all of the ingredients for the sauce/glaze into the bag and shook everything up until evenly coated. 

Once this was done, I heated up some olive oil and added garlic as directed by the recipe. I then dumped the contents of the bag into the skillet on medium heat and covered for about 5 minutes; stirring occasionally until cooked. 

The flavor wasn't as strong as it is in the original recipe, but it does cover each piece much more evenly and makes it much faster to cook. I think it's a good way to get the dish done quick if you have other items you're cooking at the same time.

Added mushrooms and onions when cooking garlic. I love this recipe!! Guest were impressed and asked for seconds!! Served with au gratin potatoes and green beans this time last time i used mashed potatoes

I did not read any reviews before I cooked the meal. Nor did I measure seasonings or the wine lol I seasoned to taste. I used Red Romance wine from Cooper's Hawk *all I had in the house*. Seasonings: red crushed pepper flakes, cajun style seasoning, paprika, and sriracha. I followed the cooking instructions! The chicken was 5 star restaurant delicious...so good and juicy.

WOW WOW WOW! Tonight I made this delicious dish, I added mushrooms and for a side some oven roasted potatoes. So much flavor and the chicken is super tender. The only thing I did differently was cover with a lid and put it in the oven for 20 minutes and basted twice. Definitely will make again.

This was excellent. I didn't cover my chicken and I used ACV instead of regular or rice vinegar. It smelled and taste so good. I'll have to blog about this of course giving credit to the original source! Great recipe!
I think I cooked the chicken longer than needed; my fault so it came out a little dry. I will try again
Loved it. Note, I added garlic after browning chicken so it would not burn

There‚Äôs several things wrong with this recipe. You can avoid them by reading the other reviews. I‚Äôll just note that if followed as written you‚Äôll have the chicken on heat for 35 - 40 minutes and it will be overcooked. You should remove the breasts when they get close to done and continue to reduce the sauce, then return them for a last heat-up.

I made this with 2 chicken breasts, so I decreased the ingredients a bit.
It was quite tasy, but next time I would use more sugar and a smaller skillet. The red wine was too sparse around it.
It was still tasty...but I think if I changed it a bit, it would be even better!
I followed the recipe and the chicken was way overcooked. I'll try it again taking into account the other reviews and definitely cut the cooking time.
Needs water! Also added 8 oz mushrooms, cayenne pepper, and savory.
I made it with white wine instead of red i also added more paprika then said and i added a teaspoon of garlic powder and it wasnt to sweet it was perfect

This recipe is salvageable if one uses perhaps a tablespoon of sugar (or less) instead of a cup. I modified the recipe to use only a half cup of sugar and it was still way too sweet. I couldn't eat my rice that had the sauce from the chicken on it. And I rinsed all the remaining sauce off the leftover chicken in the hopes of salvaging it with some savory flavoring later.
What I did like about this recipe is its simplicity. At least I've got a base to use for further experimentation - without sugar.

I love this recipe when altered a bit but as many others have said it is very sweet. I personally make it with 1/4 C. Brown Sugar and 3/4 C. Red wine and it turns out fine. But alter it to your liking.

I made this as written, except attempting to leave the skillet uncovered during braising. The sauce reduced too quickly, and I put the lid back on to try to recover it. The chicken and sauce still tasted very good, but next time I think I will leave it covered for at least the first half of the time, then try uncovering it closer to the end to thicken up the sauce.
I found the cooking times listed to be a little long. Great taste, used some leftover red wine. Good with rice for the sauce.

Threw this together very last minute but it was amazing! I used more garlic than called for. I also mixed dark brown sugar and white because I had no light brown sugar but it came out fantastic. The sauce is very good and we plan to use it for other meats and seafood.
Not bad, need some tweeks
Not bad, need some tweeks
I think I will reduce the amount of brown sugar next time by a little but other than that, I loved the dish. I also added some fresh mushrooms into the dish that made it just a little better for me.
Recipe was so easy to follow! My husband and I loved it! Perfect for an at home date night.

A family favorite since my high school years, and the first dinner I ever cooked.. this dish is beautiful, and I think best served with a few tweaks: a pinch or so of cayenne, a dollop of sour cream on the side of the plate, and you should definitely cut up the chicken into hearty chunks before you cook it! The delicious taste of the sauce and the novelty of the color it leaves on the chicken is part of the whole point, so more surface area is better!
Tasted like bourbon chicken from the mall. The kids and I enjoyed. I used boneless, skinless thighs. A quarter cup of brown sugar would have sufficed. I used half still a little sweet.
Way too much sugar. Could not taste any other flavors. Such a shame.

I made this recipe as it was written, although I did change the serving size down to 4. 

It was absolutely delicious. I served it on a bed of sticky rice with a side of sweet white corn. The chicken was moist and tender, the sauce was not too thin and not too thick and it tasted really, really good. 

I will definitely make this again. It was a tad spicy for my young daughter so next time I may tone down the paprika, but for adults this recipe was a winner as is.

This recipe is DELICIOUSS!! The red wine basting keeps the chicken moist. I followed the recipe with a slight adaptation in garlic and spice; I was out of garlic and paprika but I had a paprika, garlic, salt and pepper spice mix so I used that as an alternative. I basted the chicken every 5 minutes and it was ready in 20 minutes as the recipe called for. Served it over rice and poured some of the red wine over the rice and it was phenomenal. I don't generally like chicken breast but this recipe I will keep making. Thank you!

Pleasantly surprised! I love dishes with wine, especially red wine. After reading the other reviews, I only used 1/4 cup of brown sugar and 1/2 a teaspoon of paprika, along with my cup of Cabernet wine. The other change I made, I used chicken thighs instead of breasts. I‚Äôm not sure what I did different than others but even tho I covered the skillet, after 10 minutes of simmering I had to add more wine and decided to add about 1/2 cup of chicken broth too. At the 20 minute mark, my chicken had a super thick glaze, so I removed it from the heat while I finished making mashed cauliflower (instead of carby mashed potatoes) and asparagus. I told my husband that he probably wasn‚Äôt going to like the chicken because he doesn‚Äôt care for sweet meals (and it was sweet!) but he loved it and actually had seconds.

Love. loVe.LOVE! The whole family loved it including the seven and three year old!. Lots of paprika for color. Sauteed garlic and onions before adding chicken to brown. Added rosemary, basil and parsley on top of chicken along with seasoning salt. One cup of red wine to half cup of brown sugar which was could still be cut diwn slightly. A dash of soy and bam! I left the lid off during simmer as well to reduce sauce. Served it over butter garlic noddles with slivers of carrot twisted in and fresh green beans. One of my favorite recipes on here so far!!! Oh and cant forget i let the chicken marinate in the wine in the fridge while i chopped, boiled and diced...

This was good if you adjusted it to suit your tastes. As written I would say this is a sub-par dish. The amount of sugar is just way off as most of the reviewers have commented. When I made it I only put about 1T of sugar and that was enough to give added flavour. Served with a wild rice salad it was good, but not something I would rush to make again. If you are trying this recipe then I recommend to cut the sugar drastically and then play around with the flavours to suit your tastes.

loved this recipe although I have to admit that I used chicken thighs instead on breasts. I also followed what other reviews suggested. Sauteing onions and mushrooms first, removing them, sprinkling the chicken with salt, pepper and paprika and then browning the chicken and adding in wine, broth and 1/2 cup brown sugar. it was juicy and delicious !!!

I really like this recipe, but agree with most other reviewers saying to use less sugar. I only used 1/3 cup br sugar and it came out great. Dont cover, continuously spoon the sauce over the chicken the full 15 mins. Sauce was thick and perfectly sweet.
I added shallots. It was amazing!!!
this was wonderful I especially loved the sauce Would make it for company !
Far too sweet. I had to add apple cider vinegar to take the edge off the sweetness, the end result as more like a sweet and sour chicken!

I took advice of others and cut the brown sugar, wine & paprika to 1/2. I also added corn starch to thicken, sliced onions & mushrooms and let it simmer for approx. 45mins. 
Ahhh! So good! Served with brown rice and green beans!
It's amazing how the simple ingredients in this recipe came together so quickly and easily to make a delicious, restaurant-style dish.
Really liked it. I was out of cooking wine so I used Sherry. Still good.
Turned out very strange. I followed the recipe and now I have purple chicken that doesn't really taste that great...
Made it as directed and the whole family loved it!

Ugh. Red wine and brown sugar? With paprika? In spite of all the good reviews I had a feeling that this might be a nasty combination, and it was. And the recipe's cooking time for the chicken is far too long. I halved it, searing the chicken to a nice brown crust on both sides and then cooking for twelve minutes in the sauce, taking the lid off the pan for the last five. The chicken was nice and moist but the sauce was disgusting, and that was with reducing the sugar by 3/4. I reduced it down to a glaze and that made it tolerable, but I won't be making this one again. Perhaps the author of this recipe could let us know what kind of wine they used; that might help.
We felt that it was too sweet for our tastes. Simple and easy recipe to follow though.
my husband made this and it was amazing! we will be making this a staple in our house!

Made it with thighs instead of breasts and followed the recipe. When I make it again I will try less sugar and then decide which I prefer. Preparation was quick and easy. The chicken was moist, tender and delicious.

This is a wonderful recipe! I used skinned, boneless thighs instead of breasts. Sauteed about one tablespoon garlic, red onion, and some mushrooms before cooking the chicken. Set that aside and put back in after the wine was added. I added fresh ground pepper, and salted the thighs with a little kosher salt. Also used about 1/2 cup brown sugar sprinkled on both sides with the tablespoon of paprika. Added about 1 tablespoon of cornstarch to the wine to thicken the sauce. I also added about half a tablespoon of garlic salt. Decided not to drain the drippings as I thought it would give it more flavor. Awesome! Husband just LOVED it!
Just too sweet. it was like topping chicken with cotton candy.

I made this receipe. I followed the directions. Next time I might cut the brown sugar in half of what it calls for. While I was cooking the garlic and chicken I added mushrooms and the mushrooms eventually cooked down. I loved this receipe.

Wow! I was a little skeptical and expected this to be a little bland since the recipe calls for so few ingredients, but I was very pleasantly surprised. It's definitely sweet, but I like sweet. I didn't have paprika, so I used 1 tsp of chili powder instead. I was ready to use cornstarch to thicken the sauce, but just as it was almost done cooking under the lid, the sauce thickened up slightly on its own. Luckily I didn't add any cornstarch in, because as the sauce cooled it thickened even more. My boyfriend said this was one of the best meals I've cooked. I served it with tator tots from the air fryer, and the sauce went well with those, too! The sauce would be perfect for chicken and waffles! Also, I cut up the extra chicken to throw onto a salad, which I'm sure will give the salad a little sweetness.
The one thing I would change is to thicken the sauce and somehow make the chicken not so dry.

I‚Äôm only giving it 3 stars since it seems the actual recipe is not great. I followed other people‚Äôs suggestions (half the sugar) and it was great! Another reviewer suggested saut√©ed veggies with it and I did the same with onions and bell peppers. I also didn‚Äôt cook the chicken breasts fully because it would have been really dry so I did 5 minutes each side then the simmering, it ended at 155 degrees Internal temperature and was very moist and juicy. (It is a-ok to eat chicken that‚Äôs not 165 degrees depending on how long you have been cooking the chicken). All in all, the ingredients for this recipe worked well! Just half the sugar!

I halved the brown sugar, reduced the sauce and added a table spoon of Tahini sauce. Before the tahini, the sauce was incredibly sweet and without any depth of flavor. Next time I will add a little onion in with the garlic.

I read through some reviews and took the advice of others. I reduced the brown sugar, paprika and red wine. I cut my chicken breasts in halves. Seasoned with onion powder, salt and black pepper both sides before frying. 1/2 cup brown sugar. 1/2 tablespoon paprika. 2/3 cup red wine. 10 minutes each side before draining oil. Then dumped the brown sugar/paprika on chicken and poured the wine around. Simmered 20 minutes uncovered. Amazing. Definitely a keeper. Served with white rice and oven roasted asparagus.

SO delicious! I did alter the amount of ingredients. I used 1 tsp each of paprika, black pepper and salt. I used about 3/4 cup of brown sugar and about a cup of Merlot. I cooked with the lid on for 5 minutes and then removed the lid for another 10 or so to let the sauce cook down. I did not add cornstarch to thicken. I served with mashed potatoes using the extra sauce as a gravy. This will be a weekly dinner. Easy and so good!

This was great! However, I did take the suggestion of another reviewer and halved both the brown sugar and the paprika. Also--and maybe the chicken breasts I had were extra large--I had to cook it another 15 minutes before it was safe to eat...and it also turned the wine sauce into a wonderful glaze.

I added less sugar and the 1/2 cup of chicken stock and sauteed some onions as other reviewers recommended. 

I left sauce/chicken uncovered and the sauce was still too runny. I didn't have any cornstarch or flour on hand so the sauce was more like a soup with pasta noodles in my plate. This recipe needs an overhaul for the ingredients.

Even following advice from other reviewers, this still turned out awful. Pretty tasteless, and what taste was there wasn't good. I suffered through eating a bit because I was hungry, but couldn't stomach the thought of eating more. My husband managed to get down a bit more than me, but we tossed the rest.
Reduce cooking time to 5 min per side, and reduce sugar to 1/4 cup.

I don't usually like to make changes until I've tried it once, but this time I made adjustments after reading some of the reviews. I ended up reducing the brown sugar to just under half, but kept the amount of wine. Since I love the combination of chicken and rosemary, I added a half teaspoon. I also just seared the chicken and let it cook in the liquid, which I thickened slightly with cornstarch. Thanks for the recipe, everyone had seconds!
This meal was fantastic. The whole family loved it. We didn't overeat because after a few bites we didn't want much more. Our dog was, however, was delighted with the results.
Amazing dish! I cut the brown sugar in half and added a little bit of lemon pepper. Delicious!
Love this!! Cook your chicken however you want, but this sauce is awesome. Add some diced tomatoes and some butter the last few minutes
It was OK, nothing special, but that's is probably just my taste buds. I am looking for something different. It was nice for one time.
delicious and easy!!!
This recipe is delicious with a little tweaking...
Too sweet for my taste, even reducing the sugar by half.
I think the recipe is good, but definitely beware not to overcook it-- the brown sugar will turn to molasses. I think I need to take another stab at it:)

Like many others, I cut back on the sugar. Also tried dredging the chicken with Adobo prior to browning. Worked out ok. Added sauteed onions and mushrooms to the mix and had to play around with the wine sauce to get it to where we liked the taste. But all in all, a decent recipe, IMHO. I would recommend this one.

I used red chilli pepper instead of paprika, and regardless it came out great. After basting the chicken for a period of time I took the breasts and set them in a warmed bowl and simmered the rest of the sauce down into a thicker sauce to drizzle.

If I make it again I might try adding red miso.
Made it as listed and it was fabulous! It was incredibly easy and would be great using pork as well. Thank you again!
Delicious! Followed the recipe

Shut up! This is delicious!! I followed the recipe mostly, but only had boneless skinless thighs so used those, added 1 T of salted butter and a thinly sliced onion when sauteing garlic. Basted as directed and simmered low and slow. It my sauce thickened up nicely. I will add mushrooms next time, or sure. Highly recommend for an easy and tasty meal!
Too sweet for my taste. My fiance agreed. I might try it again with less sugar.

Quick & easy, first time I made this I used whole boneless, skinless chicken thighs, second time I diced the thighs up and added garlic, leeks and mushrooms. Cut back on the brown sugar as others recommended, and had it over rice. Tastes like a slightly sweet coq au vin!
I love this dish. I think I will use wine in all my cooking.

Reduced the recipe to 4 servings, using boneless breasts, which I pounded flat to cook evenly. Reduced sugar, as some reviewers suggested. Greatly reduced cooking time (4 minutes to a side) and it was still overcooked. Used cornstarch to thicken gravy, which worked well. But just didn't love the flavor. Garlic was too prominent and didn't blend with sugar and red wine. Won't be making this again.
We used Marsala wine and it came the closest to restaurant Chicken Marsala we've been able to come up with. Very tasty!
I did reduce sugar and paprika as others suggested and this was great!! Will make again
My family loved it and I will fix it again
I made this for my husband as I don't eat meat. It was very easy and he loved it.
Nope, let it just the way the recipe was. It was geat'

Good. Just good. Not Great, not an "Out-of-Body Experience," not "Best Chicken Ever," and not "Life Changing" in any way. I agree with many reviewing cooks that the flavors do not blend. You taste wine. Lots of wine. You taste the sugar. Lots of sugar. And then you taste garlic with a hint of chicken. I cooked the chicken in sauce for 15-20 minutes, removing the lid half-way to reduce the sauce a bit. It did reduce, but the chicken, as many others commented, dried. Anything above the sauce line in the pan lost moisture. Still, it was good. I would assume that the flavor would change slightly with the choice of wine variety. It was worth the try, but won't go on my favorite list.
Should have read the reviews before I made. Followed recipe, but found it forgetful and too messy to make again.
just I like
yes loved it
Added some scallions for some contrast to the sweet. Nice simple, yummy dish.
Great on top of a salad with fruity dressing.
So easy and quick to make with just a few ingredients. It is delicious! So elegant you could definitely serve it for a dinner party.

Other than using less brown sugar I followed this recipe. My family loved it and asked for it again the next week. I used a Woodbridge Cabernet Sauvignon so, not a real expensive wine, (I only mention it because no one else specified what kind of red wine they used.) which was good enough for us. I sprinkled about a tablespoon of sugar on the chicken pieces while they browned then flipped them over. Oh, I guess I used thighs instead of breasts too. Other than that followed the recipe.
I will definitely make it again. My husband loved th sauce. It's a keeper.

I had to make some changes. Like many others, I saut√©ed onion and fresh mushrooms with the garlic. Removed from pan and then seared the chicken, which I put the paprika and salt on. I then used 1/4 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup chicken broth, and 1/2 cup red wine and simmered the chicken and veggies for 30 minutes. I then thickened using some chicken broth and 1 tablespoon of flour. Delicious. Will make again.
